description: From Middle English sitten, from Old English sittan, from Proto-West Germanic *sittjan, from Proto-Germanic *sitjaną, from Proto-Indo-European *sed- (“sit”).

entries.meaning: (mining) Subsidence of the roof of a coal mine.
(rare, Buddhism) An event, usually lasting one full day or more, where the primary goal is to sit in meditation.

verbs.description: sit (third-person singular simple present sits, present participle sitting, simple past sat or (dated, poetic) sate, past participle sat or (archaic, dialectal) sitten)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative, of a person) To be in a position in which the upper body is upright and supported by the buttocks.
examples: He is so fair, without lease, he seems full well to sit on this.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a person) To move oneself into such a position.
(intransitive, of an object) To occupy a given position.
examples: The temple has sat atop that hill for centuries.
Jim's pet parrot sat on his left shoulder.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To remain in a state of repose; to rest; to abide; to rest in any position or condition.
examples: And Moses said to  […]  the children of Reuben, Shall your brothren go to war, and shall ye sit here?

entries.meaning: (government) To be a member of a deliberative body.
examples: I currently sit on a standards committee.

entries.meaning: (law, government) Of a legislative or, especially, a judicial body such as a court, to be in session.
examples: In what city is the circuit court sitting for this session.

entries.meaning: To lie, rest, or bear; to press or weigh.
To be adjusted; to fit.
(intransitive, of an agreement or arrangement) To be accepted or acceptable; to work.
examples: How will this new contract sit with the workers?
I don’t think it will sit well.
The violence in these video games sits awkwardly with their stated aim of educating children.

entries.meaning: (transitive, causative) To cause to be seated or in a sitting posture; to furnish a seat to.
examples: Sit him in front of the TV and he might watch for hours.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To accommodate in seats; to seat.
examples: The dining room table sits eight comfortably.

entries.meaning: (US, transitive, intransitive) To babysit.
examples: I'm going to sit for them on Thursday.
I need to find someone to sit my kids on Friday evening for four hours.

entries.meaning: (transitive, Australia, New Zealand, UK) To take, to undergo or complete (an examination or test).
To cover and warm eggs for hatching, as a fowl; to brood; to incubate.
examples: The partridge sitteth on eggs, and hatcheth them not.

entries.meaning: To take a position for the purpose of having some artistic representation of oneself made, such as a picture or a bust.
examples: I'm sitting for a painter this evening.

entries.meaning: To have position, as at the point blown from; to hold a relative position; to have direction.
examples: like a good miller that knows how to grind, which way soever the wind sits

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To keep one's seat when faced with (a blow, attack); to endure, to put up with. [13th–19th c.]
examples: Louisa, who  […]  had but ill born the commencement of this conversation, could sit it no longer, and hastily throwing up the sash, complained of the intense heat of the room.

entries.meaning: (informal) Short for situation.
